Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Solid-State NMR Spectrometer Console for Advanced NMR Spectroscopy of Complex Organic and Hybrid Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) programs. Professor Klaus Schmidt-Rohr from Brandeis University and colleagues have acquired a console upgrade for a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer with solid state capabilities. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as the study of biologically-relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is important to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, forensics and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows via independent student research and traditional academic research and coursework. The instrument is available to researchers nationwide. Locally, the requested instrument is shared with interested users at Brandeis University and in the Greater Boston area for hands-on NMR measurements.

The award of a 400 MHz NMR console with solid state capabilities is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as: (a) determining the chemical structure of protective aromatic-rich organic overlayers on mesoporous oxide supports, (b) quantifying functional-group concentrations in cross-linked stimuli-responsive or post-modified catalytically active polymers, (c) studying the structure of catalytically active metal organic frameworks, including the proximity of different linkers, (d) characterizing a biological underwater adhesive, and (e) determining the structure of natural organic matter in the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer console and probe head were installed and utilized in structural characterizations of complex organic materials by solid-state NMR using advanced pulse programs, many of which were developed in the PI's group. Quantitative and comprehensive composition analyses of multi-component polymer microcapsules, air-oxidized chars, hydrothermal carbon, catalytically active metal-organic frameworks, decomposing biomass, de- and re-crystallized cellulose for biofuels, carbon nanothreads, fluorescent nanoparticles, biodegradable co-polyesters, etc. were performed in collaboration with numerous materials research groups in academia and industry. The detailed and quantitative structural information from NMR provides a basis for the rational development of materials with improved properties.

Chromophores and fluorophores in the 1 - 20 wt% range were quantified, clarifying structure-property relations in photoswitchable materials and fluorescent polymer dots. Different environments of cellulose chains were resolved and quantified in cellulose processed for biofuel production, using NMR relaxation-time filtering. This enabled more realistic modeling of the cellulose degradation process. Unexpected inhomogeneity discovered in amorphous pharmaceutical dispersions was analyzed quantitatively. In biodegradable semicrystalline PB-S/A copolyesters, asymmetric incorporation of minority monomer into the crystals of the majority monomer was observed directly: monomer S incorporates into majority-A crystals, but not vice versa. This affects crystallinity and ultimately biodegradability. The clustering of 13C-labeled chain ends at the crystallite surfaces in semicrystalline polymers, unexpected to many experts, was detected using a suite of advanced NMR experiments. Measurements of the concentration of chain ends in hydrolyzed cellulose indicated that widely accepted indirect methods for determining the length of cellulose chains are quite inaccurate.

As part of the Broader Impacts of this proposal, the PI comprehensively edited Wikipedia articles on "Nuclear magnetic resonance" and "Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance" for accuracy and clarity, making over 200 specific corrections or improvements and adding explanatory paragraphs both on fundamentals and advanced topics. This should help interested students and educators understand the subject better and more quickly.
